summary: Post-war Snarry would include: Severus feeling self-conscious about being Harry’s first because of his age.  Harry being at hand...
body:
Post-war Snarry would include:

  • Severus feeling self-conscious about being Harry’s first because of his age.
  • Harry being at hand to help with Severus’ recovery.
  • Severus allowing Harry to be dominant on occasion.
  • Harry teaching a awkward Severus how to kiss.
  • Severus feeling more comfortable about sharing stories from his childhood with Harry, who eagerly listens to every word.
  • Harry coaxing Severus out on dates at fancy restaurants and the cinema.
  • Severus and Harry cooking together and sharing recipes and techniques.
  • Harry curling up with Severus and reading together.

summary: Since no one asked, I’m going to give my take on the sexuality and Hogwarts houses of the next gen characters. (PS. I do not...
body:
Since no one asked, I’m going to give my take on the sexuality and Hogwarts houses of the next gen characters. (PS. I do not think that The Cursed Child is canon (you can if you want), so therefor I will not count what houses they are in in that play. However, I do agree with some of them.)

  • Albus Severus Potter, son of Harry and Ginny - Gay - Slytherin


  • Dominique Weasley, daughter of Bill and Fleur - Pansexual - Gryffindor


  • Edward “Teddy” Lupin, son of Remus and Tonks - Straight - Hufflepuff


  • Fred Weasley II, son of George and Angelina - Bisexual - Gryffindor


  • Hugo Weasley, son of Ron and Hermione - Pansexual - Gryffindor


  • James Sirius Potter, son of Harry and Ginny - Straight - Gryffindor


  • Lily Luna Potter, daughter of Harry and Ginny - Gay - Gryffindor


  • Louis Weasley, son of Bill and Fleur - Straight - Gryffindor


  • Lucy Weasley, daughter of Audrey and Percy - Asexual - Slytherin


  • Molly Weasley II, daughter of Audrey and Percy - Gay - Ravenclaw


  • Rose Weasley, daughter of Hermione and Ron - Been with several genders but doesn’t wanna put a label on herself - Gryffindor


  • Roxxane Weasley, daughter of George and Angelina - Bisexual - Slytherin


  • Scorpius Malfoy, son of Draco and Astoria - Gay - Hufflepuff


  • Victorie Weasley, daughter of Bill and Fleur - Straight - Ravenclaw

Just to be clear this is my thoughts on these characters and my headcanons. I’m not saying that this is fact or that you have to have the same opinion as me, if you have interpreted these characters differently that is totally fine by me and I respect your opinion.

body:
Letters

Premise: Reader x Felix

A/N: So, this is legit my first ever fanfic. I think Felix is cool. Whether you swing him with MC or with Chester, idc. Maybe I’ll try a Felix x Chester thing sometime.

I dunno, I just wanted to add a lil somethin to the community haha. …and I’m new again on Tumblr so I have no friends to tag. :’( Be my friend pls

Pretend the curse breaker gang is just a year or two below the game’s prefects. There’s a continuation to this (BECAUSE I WROTE IT TOO DAMN LONG FOR TUMBLR IS2G), but maybe if this gets a bit of traction idk whatevs. If not, for now, have some fluff.

××××××

It’s been a year since Felix’s leaving Hogwarts. Now fulfilling his ambitions as a dragonologist apprentice in Romania—a dream he realized against the Rosier Death Eater legacy—you thought about how much more different he was.

You remembered the evening he told you the news. He was chosen as one of only three apprentices of the legendary dragon expert Maurice Roirdan (who was mentored under the greatest dragonologist Quang Po). Outside both his duties as a former Slytherin prefect and as the now-estranged son of Evan Rosier, you saw him light up—the truest, purest Felix he had never shown anyone else. And you knew it was well-deserved. He was intelligent, hardworking, charismatic, and above all, the absolute poster-boy of the Slytherin House; who else would deserve the opportunity other than him?

And you were the first one he told. That evening was full of firsts, now that you thought about it. The first time you saw Felix’s raw emotions. The first time he spoke to you as honestly as a dear friend. The first time your fingers laced together. The first time he pulled you into his arms that he was practically radiating warmth with so much joy. The first time you saw—and he showed you!—how unabashedly happy he was.

You reasoned that perhaps you were both just utterly intoxicated by the night’s festivities. They did say that Hogwarts’ Yule Ball was always going to be a night to remember and it certainly was. The happiness that flowed between you was made even more contagious that time.

Because when your and Felix Rosier’s lips met, neither of you ever forgot it.

“Post’s here,” Ben Copper announced, ducking beneath his textbook to avoid the sudden downpour of parcels. A package dropped on top of his OWLs notes as did the rest of the group’s.

Care packages from the eager parents of the school’s seniors. It was as traditional as the annual onslaught of third years on their first Hogsmeade visit. With seventh year students revising for their dreaded OWLs, parents and guardians usually delivered gifts and messages of support and good luck. When your parents learned this, they constantly asked what your favourite sweets were. It looked as though they threw in a few more goodies too.

Just as your hands touched the box before you, a second, smaller parcel dropped on top of it. You looked up and the second owl seemed to squawk at you in apology. You picked it up and read the name—yours, in an unmistakable penmanship.

Tulip Karasu was the first to notice and badgered you. “Keeping secrets again, eh?” she teased. “Is it a little good luck charm from your secret admirer? ‘Good luck on your OWLs! I’ll be thinking of you!’” she said, laughing. The others snickered and giggled too.

It was common knowledge to your circle that someone had been consistently sending you letters. What wasn’t common knowledge was that these letters came from your former prefect Felix. And they weren’t just any sort of letters…

But no one needed to know that. You were just thankful you’d kept that secret from them successfully for so long. (And whether they had an inkling or not, none of them had ever given you comment on it.)

You simply shrugged. “We’ve got our OWLs to worry about. Come on, no distractions.” Just to prove your point, you set aside even your family’s gifts and opened your Divination book where you left off.

-

Your friends retreated to the Three Broomsticks for an evening butterbeer fix or two. You had half the mind to join them, but declined instead. Felix’s latest letter was still on your mind. (You felt a little guilty lying to them, but the heart bent over backwards for the silliest reasons sometimes. They’ll realize it themselves someday, you convince yourself.)

Closing the door behind you, you took out the parcel from your robe’s pocket. A small pale envelope was wrapped on an even smaller box with a piece of twine. No frills, nothing fancy; as straightforward and simply elegant as its sender.

First the letter:

Ma cherie,

You must be terribly busy with your revising, so please don’t worry about responding too soon—though it would always be appreciated. Don’t forget the mnemonics I taught you.

Enough about the OWLs for now. I’m sure you’re aching for a breather.

Romania is more than I ever imagined. The barracks overlook these mountain ranges where we were told a family of Ridgebacks have nested. We’re traveling there tomorrow. I’m not looking forward to another hatchling following me around again after the last one singed my favourite boots.

The hide gloves you gave me are, thankfully, still intact. Thank you again, by the way. Saved me the blisters Giorgio and Harris received from roping the Silvertalon bull. Now they’re asking where these gloves are from!

I can’t wait until the holidays to see you. I know it’s months away, but it’s the very thing that’s keeping me going. I miss you terribly—admittedly like you said I would.

But I haven’t bawled my eyes out, so that counts as a point for me. And no, it’s not because the lads would endlessly tease me over it, but because it’s too cold to cry.

Before you chastise me in your next letter, I will say I could certainly use your embrace right now.

Happy?

Yours,

Felix

You smiled, clutching the letter close to your chest. (You didn’t care how cliché it might have looked.) Glancing back to the letter, you were surprised by the little note Felix quickly scribbled last near the bottom of the parchment:

PS. Think of me when you wear this.

The parcel! You almost forgot about the nondescript box tied to the letter. Unwrapping it quickly, you lifted the cardboard lid open and you felt your smile grow wider. Sitting in the middle of the box was a gold pendant of a dragon taking flight.

It was fitting of the sender and oddly comforting how subtle it looked around your neck. You knew then and there you were never going to take it off.

You had to reply to him, regardless of his saying you needed the time for study.

Dear Felix,

I should be studying—and I am, I swear!—but when I read your letter, I just couldn’t keep myself from sending one back right away.

I miss you, you know I do. Not in the way the rest of Slytherin does, but you know how much I do.

You should also know, by the way, that even the first years have built a sort of respect for their first prefect—you’re a bit of a celebrity here now! Everyone is far more determined to earn House points and I think that was your doing. I even heard rumours that Professor Snape sometimes slips, comparing the current prefect to you. I guess that means he liked you, in his special little Snape-y way.

Thank you for the necklace too. I absolutely love it! And telling me to think of you whenever I wear it… Well, I have no plans of ever taking it off.

Romania sounds breath-taking and it also sounds like your work there is hectic! A good kind of hectic, I assume? No matter, I know you of all people are completely capable of doing an amazing job there.

By the way, Charlie’s really keen on applying for the apprenticeship there too after Hogwarts. Do you have any tips for him?

I’m sorry for rambling. You know how excited I get whenever you write me things. And I know you want me to get back to my revising. Your letters always give me that much-needed breath of fresh air.

Well, back to the grind. Write me again soon please?

You signed your name at the lower portion of the parchment and added one more thing:

PS. Come back to me sooner and maybe we can arrange something more than an embrace.

You felt a light flush rising in your cheeks as you sealed the letter. After dipping your quill in some ink, you addressed it to Felix—a script he once said looked like chicken scratch, but still gave him a sense of comfort to read. You laughed to yourself at the memory of it and kissed his name on the envelope. It was a little too late at night to head to the owlery to send it, but you reminded yourself to get to it first thing tomorrow.

-

You wondered if Felix realises that his immediate reply to your reply defeats his own point. He incessantly reminds you to study hard for the OWLs, yet quickly sends another letter.

Your relationship is special that way, you reasoned. Felix can be focused on a myriad of things, but when it came to you, you could read his attention was all on you. You made a note to tease him about this in your next response—it was endearing, but you knew better than to be a distraction and vice versa.

But basically you thought it was cute.

Ma cherie,

I really do hope I’m not keeping you from your OWLs. No matter how smart you think you are—and talented, and skilled, and charming—do not fail Slytherin. Please do this for our House, for me.

Really? A celebrity? Sounds like a bad fad. Don’t tell me Slytherin’s gone soft now that I’ve left. If it has, Hufflepuff may have doubled its badgers.

And please never ever say ‘Snape-y’ again.

Also, you mean Charles Weasley, right? I don’t know what to say. There’s so few of us to reference our skills and credentials. I’m telling you that both Harris and Giorgio are far different from each other and from me.

I’m glad to hear you like the gift. The nearest village I purchased it from is not near at all and that was the best thing I could find there. If you plan to wear it that much, you might not get any studying done at all!

I do wish I could see it on you though.

Yours,

Felix

PS. More than an embrace? Very tempting.

Your cheeks turned so scarlet that your face could have been mistaken for a Gryffindor banner. Your stomach felt like the first time you did a Loop the Loop in Flying class and you tried your damnedest to hold it in. Your friends didn’t seem to read the excitement you hid inside as you re-joined their study table.

“Where’s the book…?” Rowan Khanna asked. You volunteered earlier to search for some reference material for brewing liquid luck in one of the library aisles, only to return empty-handed.

Of all the damned things to remind you, steeling you from studying! Felix Felicis!

You swore sibilantly, remembering. Madam Pince shushed you from several rows away. (Barnaby Lee once commented that Madam Pince must have been part elephant, considering how powerful her hearing must be. That was, until Penny Haywood slapped the back of his head to correct his analogy.)

“I’ll be right back,” you said, feigning a groan. “All this studying’s draining my head…”

“We’ll take a break soon, don’t worry,” Rowan said, then addressed the Ravenclaw. “After all, it’s looking rather pointless for you to defend, Andre.”

“I’m telling you, Khanna, Felixempra is done left to right!” argued Andre Egwu.

“Who draws a figure eight like that? It doesn’t matter! Even if you ask Zygmunt Budge, you could easily ruin a perfectly brewed batch of Felix Felicis!”

Andre threw his hands up. “I don’t know what else to tell you, Rowan. I read what I read and I will stand by it. Felixempra: left to right.”

“Let’s see that book then,” grumbled your best friend.

As you walked away, you couldn’t help but conceal a smile from hearing Felix’s name being spoken again and again.

Damn it. Stop blushing so much.

reblog.comment:
Letters

Premise: Reader x Felix

A/N: So, this is legit my first ever fanfic. I think Felix is cool. Whether you swing him with MC or with Chester, idc. Maybe I’ll try a Felix x Chester thing sometime.

I dunno, I just wanted to add a lil somethin to the community haha. …and I’m new again on Tumblr so I have no friends to tag. :’( Be my friend pls

Pretend the curse breaker gang is just a year or two below the game’s prefects. There’s a continuation to this (BECAUSE I WROTE IT TOO DAMN LONG FOR TUMBLR IS2G), but maybe if this gets a bit of traction idk whatevs. If not, for now, have some fluff.

××××××

It’s been a year since Felix’s leaving Hogwarts. Now fulfilling his ambitions as a dragonologist apprentice in Romania—a dream he realized against the Rosier Death Eater legacy—you thought about how much more different he was.

You remembered the evening he told you the news. He was chosen as one of only three apprentices of the legendary dragon expert Maurice Roirdan (who was mentored under the greatest dragonologist Quang Po). Outside both his duties as a former Slytherin prefect and as the now-estranged son of Evan Rosier, you saw him light up—the truest, purest Felix he had never shown anyone else. And you knew it was well-deserved. He was intelligent, hardworking, charismatic, and above all, the absolute poster-boy of the Slytherin House; who else would deserve the opportunity other than him?

And you were the first one he told. That evening was full of firsts, now that you thought about it. The first time you saw Felix’s raw emotions. The first time he spoke to you as honestly as a dear friend. The first time your fingers laced together. The first time he pulled you into his arms that he was practically radiating warmth with so much joy. The first time you saw—and he showed you!—how unabashedly happy he was.

You reasoned that perhaps you were both just utterly intoxicated by the night’s festivities. They did say that Hogwarts’ Yule Ball was always going to be a night to remember and it certainly was. The happiness that flowed between you was made even more contagious that time.

Because when your and Felix Rosier’s lips met, neither of you ever forgot it.

“Post’s here,” Ben Copper announced, ducking beneath his textbook to avoid the sudden downpour of parcels. A package dropped on top of his OWLs notes as did the rest of the group’s.

Care packages from the eager parents of the school’s seniors. It was as traditional as the annual onslaught of third years on their first Hogsmeade visit. With seventh year students revising for their dreaded OWLs, parents and guardians usually delivered gifts and messages of support and good luck. When your parents learned this, they constantly asked what your favourite sweets were. It looked as though they threw in a few more goodies too.

Just as your hands touched the box before you, a second, smaller parcel dropped on top of it. You looked up and the second owl seemed to squawk at you in apology. You picked it up and read the name—yours, in an unmistakable penmanship.

Tulip Karasu was the first to notice and badgered you. “Keeping secrets again, eh?” she teased. “Is it a little good luck charm from your secret admirer? ‘Good luck on your OWLs! I’ll be thinking of you!’” she said, laughing. The others snickered and giggled too.

It was common knowledge to your circle that someone had been consistently sending you letters. What wasn’t common knowledge was that these letters came from your former prefect Felix. And they weren’t just any sort of letters…

But no one needed to know that. You were just thankful you’d kept that secret from them successfully for so long. (And whether they had an inkling or not, none of them had ever given you comment on it.)

You simply shrugged. “We’ve got our OWLs to worry about. Come on, no distractions.” Just to prove your point, you set aside even your family’s gifts and opened your Divination book where you left off.

-

Your friends retreated to the Three Broomsticks for an evening butterbeer fix or two. You had half the mind to join them, but declined instead. Felix’s latest letter was still on your mind. (You felt a little guilty lying to them, but the heart bent over backwards for the silliest reasons sometimes. They’ll realize it themselves someday, you convince yourself.)

Closing the door behind you, you took out the parcel from your robe’s pocket. A small pale envelope was wrapped on an even smaller box with a piece of twine. No frills, nothing fancy; as straightforward and simply elegant as its sender.

First the letter:

Ma cherie,

You must be terribly busy with your revising, so please don’t worry about responding too soon—though it would always be appreciated. Don’t forget the mnemonics I taught you.

Enough about the OWLs for now. I’m sure you’re aching for a breather.

Romania is more than I ever imagined. The barracks overlook these mountain ranges where we were told a family of Ridgebacks have nested. We’re traveling there tomorrow. I’m not looking forward to another hatchling following me around again after the last one singed my favourite boots.

The hide gloves you gave me are, thankfully, still intact. Thank you again, by the way. Saved me the blisters Giorgio and Harris received from roping the Silvertalon bull. Now they’re asking where these gloves are from!

I can’t wait until the holidays to see you. I know it’s months away, but it’s the very thing that’s keeping me going. I miss you terribly—admittedly like you said I would.

But I haven’t bawled my eyes out, so that counts as a point for me. And no, it’s not because the lads would endlessly tease me over it, but because it’s too cold to cry.

Before you chastise me in your next letter, I will say I could certainly use your embrace right now.

Happy?

Yours,

Felix

You smiled, clutching the letter close to your chest. (You didn’t care how cliché it might have looked.) Glancing back to the letter, you were surprised by the little note Felix quickly scribbled last near the bottom of the parchment:

PS. Think of me when you wear this.

The parcel! You almost forgot about the nondescript box tied to the letter. Unwrapping it quickly, you lifted the cardboard lid open and you felt your smile grow wider. Sitting in the middle of the box was a gold pendant of a dragon taking flight.

It was fitting of the sender and oddly comforting how subtle it looked around your neck. You knew then and there you were never going to take it off.

You had to reply to him, regardless of his saying you needed the time for study.

Dear Felix,

I should be studying—and I am, I swear!—but when I read your letter, I just couldn’t keep myself from sending one back right away.

I miss you, you know I do. Not in the way the rest of Slytherin does, but you know how much I do.

You should also know, by the way, that even the first years have built a sort of respect for their first prefect—you’re a bit of a celebrity here now! Everyone is far more determined to earn House points and I think that was your doing. I even heard rumours that Professor Snape sometimes slips, comparing the current prefect to you. I guess that means he liked you, in his special little Snape-y way.

Thank you for the necklace too. I absolutely love it! And telling me to think of you whenever I wear it… Well, I have no plans of ever taking it off.

Romania sounds breath-taking and it also sounds like your work there is hectic! A good kind of hectic, I assume? No matter, I know you of all people are completely capable of doing an amazing job there.

By the way, Charlie’s really keen on applying for the apprenticeship there too after Hogwarts. Do you have any tips for him?

I’m sorry for rambling. You know how excited I get whenever you write me things. And I know you want me to get back to my revising. Your letters always give me that much-needed breath of fresh air.

Well, back to the grind. Write me again soon please?

You signed your name at the lower portion of the parchment and added one more thing:

PS. Come back to me sooner and maybe we can arrange something more than an embrace.

You felt a light flush rising in your cheeks as you sealed the letter. After dipping your quill in some ink, you addressed it to Felix—a script he once said looked like chicken scratch, but still gave him a sense of comfort to read. You laughed to yourself at the memory of it and kissed his name on the envelope. It was a little too late at night to head to the owlery to send it, but you reminded yourself to get to it first thing tomorrow.

-

You wondered if Felix realises that his immediate reply to your reply defeats his own point. He incessantly reminds you to study hard for the OWLs, yet quickly sends another letter.

Your relationship is special that way, you reasoned. Felix can be focused on a myriad of things, but when it came to you, you could read his attention was all on you. You made a note to tease him about this in your next response—it was endearing, but you knew better than to be a distraction and vice versa.

But basically you thought it was cute.

Ma cherie,

I really do hope I’m not keeping you from your OWLs. No matter how smart you think you are—and talented, and skilled, and charming—do not fail Slytherin. Please do this for our House, for me.

Really? A celebrity? Sounds like a bad fad. Don’t tell me Slytherin’s gone soft now that I’ve left. If it has, Hufflepuff may have doubled its badgers.

And please never ever say ‘Snape-y’ again.

Also, you mean Charles Weasley, right? I don’t know what to say. There’s so few of us to reference our skills and credentials. I’m telling you that both Harris and Giorgio are far different from each other and from me.

I’m glad to hear you like the gift. The nearest village I purchased it from is not near at all and that was the best thing I could find there. If you plan to wear it that much, you might not get any studying done at all!

I do wish I could see it on you though.

Yours,

Felix

PS. More than an embrace? Very tempting.

Your cheeks turned so scarlet that your face could have been mistaken for a Gryffindor banner. Your stomach felt like the first time you did a Loop the Loop in Flying class and you tried your damnedest to hold it in. Your friends didn’t seem to read the excitement you hid inside as you re-joined their study table.

“Where’s the book…?” Rowan Khanna asked. You volunteered earlier to search for some reference material for brewing liquid luck in one of the library aisles, only to return empty-handed.

Of all the damned things to remind you, steeling you from studying! Felix Felicis!

You swore sibilantly, remembering. Madam Pince shushed you from several rows away. (Barnaby Lee once commented that Madam Pince must have been part elephant, considering how powerful her hearing must be. That was, until Penny Haywood slapped the back of his head to correct his analogy.)

“I’ll be right back,” you said, feigning a groan. “All this studying’s draining my head…”

“We’ll take a break soon, don’t worry,” Rowan said, then addressed the Ravenclaw. “After all, it’s looking rather pointless for you to defend, Andre.”

“I’m telling you, Khanna, Felixempra is done left to right!” argued Andre Egwu.

“Who draws a figure eight like that? It doesn’t matter! Even if you ask Zygmunt Budge, you could easily ruin a perfectly brewed batch of Felix Felicis!”

Andre threw his hands up. “I don’t know what else to tell you, Rowan. I read what I read and I will stand by it. Felixempra: left to right.”

“Let’s see that book then,” grumbled your best friend.

As you walked away, you couldn’t help but conceal a smile from hearing Felix’s name being spoken again and again.

Damn it. Stop blushing so much.

You had to reply to him, regardless of his saying you needed the time for study.

Dear Felix,

I should be studying—and I am, I swear!—but when I read your letter, I just couldn’t keep myself from sending one back right away.

I miss you, you know I do. Not in the way the rest of Slytherin does, but you know how much I do.

You should also know, by the way, that even the first years have built a sort of respect for their first prefect—you’re a bit of a celebrity here now! Everyone is far more determined to earn House points and I think that was your doing. I even heard rumours that Professor Snape sometimes slips, comparing the current prefect to you. I guess that means he liked you, in his special little Snape-y way.

Thank you for the necklace too. I absolutely love it! And telling me to think of you whenever I wear it… Well, I have no plans of ever taking it off.

Romania sounds breath-taking and it also sounds like your work there is hectic! A good kind of hectic, I assume? No matter, I know you of all people are completely capable of doing an amazing job there.

By the way, Charlie’s really keen on applying for the apprenticeship there too after Hogwarts. Do you have any tips for him?

I’m sorry for rambling. You know how excited I get whenever you write me things. And I know you want me to get back to my revising. Your letters always give me that much-needed breath of fresh air.

Well, back to the grind. Write me again soon please?

You signed your name at the lower portion of the parchment and added one more thing:

PS. Come back to me sooner and maybe we can arrange something more than an embrace.

You felt a light flush rising in your cheeks as you sealed the letter. After dipping your quill in some ink, you addressed it to Felix—a script he once said looked like chicken scratch, but still gave him a sense of comfort to read. You laughed to yourself at the memory of it and kissed his name on the envelope. It was a little too late at night to head to the owlery to send it, but you reminded yourself to get to it first thing tomorrow.

-

You wondered if Felix realises that his immediate reply to your reply defeats his own point. He incessantly reminds you to study hard for the OWLs, yet quickly sends another letter.

Your relationship is special that way, you reasoned. Felix can be focused on a myriad of things, but when it came to you, you could read his attention was all on you. You made a note to tease him about this in your next response—it was endearing, but you knew better than to be a distraction and vice versa.

But basically you thought it was cute.

Ma cherie,

I really do hope I’m not keeping you from your OWLs. No matter how smart you think you are—and talented, and skilled, and charming—do not fail Slytherin. Please do this for our House, for me.

Really? A celebrity? Sounds like a bad fad. Don’t tell me Slytherin’s gone soft now that I’ve left. If it has, Hufflepuff may have doubled its badgers.

And please never ever say ‘Snape-y’ again.

Also, you mean Charles Weasley, right? I don’t know what to say. There’s so few of us to reference our skills and credentials. I’m telling you that both Harris and Giorgio are far different from each other and from me.

I’m glad to hear you like the gift. The nearest village I purchased it from is not near at all and that was the best thing I could find there. If you plan to wear it that much, you might not get any studying done at all!

I do wish I could see it on you though.

Yours,

Felix

PS. More than an embrace? Very tempting.

Your cheeks turned so scarlet that your face could have been mistaken for a Gryffindor banner. Your stomach felt like the first time you did a Loop the Loop in Flying class and you tried your damnedest to hold it in. Your friends didn’t seem to read the excitement you hid inside as you re-joined their study table.

“Where’s the book…?” Rowan Khanna asked. You volunteered earlier to search for some reference material for brewing liquid luck in one of the library aisles, only to return empty-handed.

Of all the damned things to remind you, steeling you from studying! Felix Felicis!

You swore sibilantly, remembering. Madam Pince shushed you from several rows away. (Barnaby Lee once commented that Madam Pince must have been part elephant, considering how powerful her hearing must be. That was, until Penny Haywood slapped the back of his head to correct his analogy.)

“I’ll be right back,” you said, feigning a groan. “All this studying’s draining my head…”

“We’ll take a break soon, don’t worry,” Rowan said, then addressed the Ravenclaw. “After all, it’s looking rather pointless for you to defend, Andre.”

“I’m telling you, Khanna, Felixempra is done left to right!” argued Andre Egwu.

“Who draws a figure eight like that? It doesn’t matter! Even if you ask Zygmunt Budge, you could easily ruin a perfectly brewed batch of Felix Felicis!”

Andre threw his hands up. “I don’t know what else to tell you, Rowan. I read what I read and I will stand by it. Felixempra: left to right.”

“Let’s see that book then,” grumbled your best friend.

As you walked away, you couldn’t help but conceal a smile from hearing Felix’s name being spoken again and again.

Damn it. Stop blushing so much.
